metadata.title: Bimetallic palladium-cobalt nanomaterials as highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane

sections.heading: Bimetallic palladium-cobalt nanomaterials as
sections.text:
highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane
Betül S‚ en a, Ays‚enur Aygün a, Aysun S‚avk a, Mehmet Harbi Çalımlı a,b, Senem Karahan Gülbay c,**, Fatih S‚ en a,*,1
a Sen Research Group, Department of Biochemistry, Dumlupınar University, 43100, Kütahya, Turkey b Tuzluca Vocational High School, Igdir University, Igdir, Turkey c Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Dokuz Eylül University, 35160, _Izmir, Turkey
a r t i c l e i n f o

sections.heading: Article history:
sections.text: Received 20 November 2018 Received in revised form 3 January 2019 Accepted 22 January 2019 Available online xxx

sections.heading: DMAB
sections.text:
Monodispersity PdCo nanoparticle Ultrasonication
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: senem.karahan@deu.e 1 http://senresearchgroup.com/.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.01.215 0360-3199/© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
Please cite this article as: S‚ en B et al., Bime dimethylamine borane, International Journ
a b s t r a c t
In this work, we report the synthesis, characterization and application of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles (PdCo@GO) for the dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane (DMAB) as a model reaction. Bimetallic graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were readily synthesized using an ultrasonic reduction technique, in which both metals of Pd and Co were reduced with GO. The dispersion of PdCo nanoparticles on the surface of GO was enhanced with the help of the ultrasonic reduction method which result in the enhancing of dispersion of both metals without any agglomeration problem. The characterization studies revealed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have a uniform, homogeneous distribution on graphene oxide and an average particle size of 3.48 ± 0.22 nm. After fully characterization of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles, they have been tried in model reaction as a catalyst and exhibited a high catalytic performance compared the previous catalysts in literature with a TOF value of 226.80 h 1. The investigation of kinetic parameters showed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have very high negative entropy (DS: 170.85 J mol 1 K 1) value and a low activation energy value (Ea: 17.53 ± 2 kJ mol 1) for the model reaction.
© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen is considered to be clean energy source since it does not cause any damage to the environment. However, some problems with the storage of hydrogen affect negatively the hydrogen economy. There are many types of hydrogen sources such as sodium borohydride, ammonia boranes,
du.tr (S.K. Gülbay), fatihs
ons LLC. Published by Els
tallic palladium-cobalt na al of Hydrogen Energy, ht
dimethylamine boranes, methylamine boranes etc. [1e15]. Among these sources, ammonia boranes (ABs) have been used many times due to their some advantages such as high hydrogen content (19.5%), ease of use, stability, and nonflammability [16e20]. Another derivative of ABs is dimethylamine borane (DMAB) which has acceptable hydrogen content, crystalline structure and a constant form in the air. The dehydrogenation reaction of dimethylamine borane takes
en1980@gmail.com (F. S‚ en).
evier Ltd. All rights reserved.
nomaterials as highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of tps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.01.215
places easily under room conditions with the use of a suitable catalyst which is shown in Scheme 1. So far, different heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts containing palladium, ruthenium, iridium, and rhodium, etc have been tested for the dehydrogenation reaction of dimethylamine borane as shown in Table 1. According to several studies in the literature [21e28], Pd based nanomaterials have been used and they have increased the stability and the catalytic activity of chemical reactions. As shown in Table 1, in our laboratory, we have also tried many catalysts for this model reaction and obtained very good performance for dehydrocoupling of AB derivatives. Especially, Pd and Co based nanomaterials have paid attention in our lastmeasurements due to their very high performance. Hence, in this study, we report the preparation and characterization of graphene oxide supported PdCo nanomaterials (PdCo@GO) exhibiting high catalytic performance for the model reaction.
The prepared nanomaterials were prepared by using the ultrasonic reduction technique and characterized by some of the advanced analytical techniques as given in supporting information. Additionally, some detailed kinetic studies of model reaction catalyzed by graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were investigated in detail.

sections.heading: Experimental methods
sections.text:
The procedure of preparing of PdCo nanoparticles decorated on GO
The graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were prepared with the help of the ultrasonic reduction technique as shown in Fig. S1. Further, the preparation of graphene oxide and the characterization techniques of prepared materials and their detailed kinetic studies for model reaction were given in supporting information. As a summary for the preparation of nanomaterial, A solution containing 25 mg/mL GO, 0.25 mmol CoCl2 and 0.25 mmol K2PdCl4 were mixed under ultrasonic conditions for a while, and then the obtained dispersion was refluxed at 85 C for 3 h. The brownish black color of the solution shows the stabilization of the palladiumcobalt nanomaterials on GO was achieved at room temperature. The prepared materials were obtained as solid materials after washing and drying process.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Characterization of graphene oxide stabilized palladium cobalt nanoparticles
The characterizations of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were performed with various analytical
Scheme 1 e The dehydrogenation reaction of DMAB with the help of a suitable catalyst.
Please cite this article as: S‚ en B et al., Bimetallic palladium-cobalt n dimethylamine borane, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, ht
techniques. For instance, the morphology, compositions and the mean particle size of the prepared graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were investigated using Transmission electron microscopy analysis as shown in Fig. 1. The mean particle size of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles was found to be 3.48 ± 0.22 nm counting over 100 particles as shown in Fig. 1b. Further, the chemical composition and morphology of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were also investigated by high resolution electron microscopy analysis as also shown in Fig. 1a. These analyses showed that all of the particles of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were nearly spherical, and they have 0.22 nm of atomic lattice fringe. Besides, there was no agglomeration of these nanoparticles during the synthesis process.
X-ray diffraction pattern was also used to reveal the crystalline structure of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. For this purpose, as shown in Fig. 2a, the X-ray diffraction pattern of both graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles and graphene oxide stabilized Pd nanoparticles showed similar patterns, but there is a small shift to the higher degree of binding energy in bimetallic nanoparticles. This case confirms the alloy structure of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. Depending on the types of the relatively strong signal of Pd compared to the Co, graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles showed mostly the characteristic peaks of Pd instead of Co.
For instance, the peaks at around 2q ¼ 40.1 , 46.5 , 68.5 , and 82.5 correspond to the characteristic peaks of Pd (111), (200), (220) and (311). Furthermore, Scherrer formula [29e31] was used to calculate the mean crystalline particle size of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. The mean particle size of the prepared nanoparticles has been found to be 3.56 nm which is in good agreement with transmission electron microscopy results. Besides, the lattice parameter value of the prepared graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles having a cubic crystalline structure was found to be 3.87 A according to below equation which also confirms the alloy structure of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles [32e35]. Sin q ¼ l ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi h2 þ k2 þ l2p
2a
The patterns of Raman spectroscopy showing the regular and irregular structure of carbon in graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles are given in Fig. 2b. Two evident peaks are seen around 1350 and 1607 cm 1 for graphene oxide and graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. D and G bands are ascribed to the E2g, and A1g symmetry, respectively. The intensity ratio of D and G bands are shownwith the ratio ID/IG ratio value to reveal the irregularities and changes in the surface of the nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 2b, the ratios of ID/IG for graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles and graphene oxide were found to be 1.14 and 1.01, respectively. An increase in irregularity is seen in the lattice of graphene oxide after the formation of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. Besides, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis was performed for the surface morphology of the prepared nanoparticles and the oxidation states of palladium and cobalt in prepared graphene oxide stabilized PdCo
anomaterials as highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of tps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.01.215
nanoparticles. Hence, the 3d region of Pd and 2p region spectrum of Co were investigated using the GaussianLorentzian technique, as well as the integration of each peak, and estimated relative intensity of species after removal
Please cite this article as: S‚ en B et al., Bimetallic palladium-cobalt na dimethylamine borane, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, ht
and smoothing of background. The binding energies found in the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyzes as shown in Fig. 3 were calculated by using a peak of C atomat 284.6 eV as a reference. The related comparisons were made with the
e particle size histogram of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo
nomaterials as highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of tps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.01.215
theoretical binding energies (Pd-3d5/2: 334.4 eV, Co-2p3/2: 781.5 eV) belonging to Pd and Co elements in the literature and the experimental binding energies (Pd-3d5/2: 333.9 eV, Co-2p3/ 2: 778.8 eV) found in available X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyzes. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyzes shows mostly the presence of the metallic state of Pd and Co. There are also some oxidized species such as Pd (II) and Co (II) as shown in Fig. 3. The peak positions shifts of the binding energies of the elements indicate the formation of the PdCo alloy structure [29e35].
After complete characterization of the prepared nanoparticles, we compared the catalytic performance of the graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles (PdCo@GO) with graphene oxide stabilized Pd nanoparticles (Pd@GO), graphene oxide stabilized Co nanoparticles (Co@GO) and physical mixture of graphene oxide stabilized Pd and graphene oxide stabilized Co nanoparticles (Pd@GO þ Co@GO) for the model reaction. The TOF values of Pd@GO, Co@GO, Pd@GOþ Co@GO, and PdCo@GO were found to be 42, 18, 64 and 226.80 h 1, respectively. These results indicate the importance of the formation of alloy structure for the model reaction.
The catalytic performance of graphene oxide supported palladium-cobalt nanoparticles for the dehydrogenation of DMAB.
The various experiments were carried out to investigate the catalytic activity of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo
nanoparticles with their different concentration in a range of 2.25e9.0 mM for the model reaction. The experimental studies revealed that the graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles had a high catalytic activity for the dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane, and the results (nH2/ nDMAB versus time) of these experiments are given in Fig. 4. In these experiments, the hydrogen release begins immediately, and the hydrogen evolution continues during the dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane. The same experimental conditions were prepared to find the effect of the concentration of DMAB (substrate) on the catalytic dehydrocoupling of DMAB catalyzed by graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. A set of experiment with different concentrations of DMAB in a range of 75e150 mM at a constant concentration graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles (PdCo: 2.25 mM) and the hydrogen evolution plot versus time is given in Fig. 5. The obtained logarithmic plots of H2 evolution rate versus time-based on both the concentration of catalyst and DMAB have slopes of 0.9146 and 0.9064, respectively. These showed that the model reaction catalyzed by current nanoparticles were first-order reactions depending upon both the concentrations of catalyst and substrate. As a summary, the following equation can be written depending on the rate of dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane catalyzed by graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles.
d 3d (a), Co 2p (b) in graphene oxide stabilized PdCo
d h ðCH3Þ2HNBH3 i dt ¼ þ d ðCH3Þ2NBH2 2 dt ¼ þ½H 2 dt
¼ ½cat 0:9146,½DMAB 0:9064
The conversion of DMAB (d ¼ ~12.6 ppm) into the product (d ¼ ~4.9 ppm) was proven using nuclear magnetic resonance analysis for themodel reaction at room conditions. In order to calculate the detailed kinetic data of the model reactions, various experiments at different temperature in a range of 20e35 C were performed for the dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane as a model reaction, and then their results are shown in Fig. 6. These results were used to obtain the Arrhenius (Fig. 7a) and Eyring plots (Fig. 7b) in order to calculate the activation parameters such as activation energy (Ea: 17.53 ± 2 kJ mol 1), activation entropy (DS:
Please cite this article as: S‚ en B et al., Bimetallic palladium-cobalt na dimethylamine borane, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, ht
170.85 J mol 1 K 1) and activation enthalpy (DH: 14.44 kJ mol 1). Additionally, these high negative entropies, the small enthalpy, and low activation energy values indicate that there is an associative mechanism in the transition state of the reaction. At the end of themodel reaction, with the help of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles as a catalyst, H2 gaswas completely released in a short period of timewith a very high TOF value of 226.80 h 1 at ambient conditions. This TOF (226.80 h 1) value of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles was compared to the other prepared catalysts in literature for the model reaction as shown in Table 1. As shown in this table, the TOF value of 226.80 h 1 is one of the best values compared to the other prepared ones. This case can be explained bifunctional mechanism of palladium and cobalt, very good stabilization of graphene oxide as a supporting agent which results in the improvement of the catalytically active surface area and optimized particle size of the prepared catalysts.
As a result of the experiments and comparisons with other catalysts in the literature, the graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles was found to be highly efficient catalyst with very good catalytic activity and stability. The probable reasons for this result are i) high stability of graphene oxide ii) the synergic effects of Pd and Co and iii) the optimumparticle size of the graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. As shown in Table 1, the TOF values of homogenous catalysts are mostly low values except Titanium based complex as shown in Ref 22 for dehydrocoupling of DMAB. However, these complexes have some problems in terms of their reusability and durability performance. The other heterogeneous based catalysts are mostly Ru and Pd based materials which have very good TOF values. Because they have very good tendency to form alloy structure with other metals. In these types of interactions, sizes matching of the metals are very important in order to get a good alloy formation in nanocatalysts. So, the prepared graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoalloy results in very good catalytic activity and stability for themodel reaction by lowering the activation parameters. By the way, in order to show the reusability and durability performance of the
nomaterials as highly efficient catalysts for dehydrocoupling of tps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.01.215
prepared catalysts, the same amount of DMAB as a substrate was added to reaction media in each cycle for the model reaction. The detailed information is given in supporting information part of the current manuscript. These experiments revealed that the prepared graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles showed almost 80% of their initial performance even after 4th runs as shown in Fig. S2. The probable reasons of the decrease in catalytic activity can be explained by the enhancing of products at the end of the catalytic reaction of DMAB and the decreasing of the surface area of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles by covering of the surface.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
As a result, highly active, stable and durable graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were synthesized, characterized and performed for the dehydrocoupling of DMAB as a model reaction and the obtained results can be summarized as shown below:
Graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were readily synthesized using an ultrasonic reduction technique, in which both Pd and Co were reduced by Graphene oxide. The dispersion of PdCo alloy nanoparticles on the surface of graphene oxide was enhanced using the ultrasonication technique, and the increasing of dispersion of nanoparticles on graphene oxide decreased the agglomeration problem of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles. The characterization studies revealed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have a uniform, monodisperse, homogeneous distribution and an average particle size of 3.48 ± 0.22 nm. The graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles exhibited a high catalytic activity with a 226.80 h 1 TOF value compared the previous catalysts in the literature (Table 1) for the model reaction. This case can be explained bifunctional mechanism of palladium and cobalt, very good stabilization of graphene oxide as a supporting agent which results in the improvement of the catalytically active surface area and optimized particle size of the prepared catalysts. The investigation of kinetic parameters showed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have a very high
Please cite this article as: S‚ en B et al., Bimetallic palladium-cobalt n dimethylamine borane, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, ht
negative entropy (DS: 170.85 J mol 1 K 1) value and a low activation energy value (Ea: 17.53 ± 2 kJ mol
1) for the dehydrogenation reaction of DMAB. This case explains the associative mechanism in the transition state of the reaction mechanism. The obtained logarithmic plots of H2 evolution rate versus time-based on both the concentration of catalyst and DMAB have slopes of 0.9146 and 0.9064, respectively. These showed that the model reaction catalyzed by current nanoparticles were first-order reactions depending upon both the concentrations of catalyst and substrate. In view of these and other advantageous properties, graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles can be used as promising catalysts for the use of DMAB as hydrogen sources in fuel cells.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, we report the synthesis, characterization and application of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles (PdCo@GO) for the dehydrocoupling of dimethylamine borane (DMAB) as a model reaction. Bimetallic graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles were readily synthesized using an ultrasonic reduction technique, in which both metals of Pd and Co were reduced with GO. The dispersion of PdCo nanoparticles on the surface of GO was enhanced with the help of the ultrasonic reduction method which result in the enhancing of dispersion of both metals without any agglomeration problem. The characterization studies revealed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have a uniform, homogeneous distribution on graphene oxide and an average particle size of 3.48 ± 0.22 nm. After fully characterization of graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles, they have been tried in model reaction as a catalyst and exhibited a high catalytic performance compared the previous catalysts in literature with a TOF value of 226.80 h . The investigation of kinetic parameters showed that graphene oxide stabilized PdCo nanoparticles have very high negative entropy (DS: 170.85 J mol 1 K ) value and a low activation energy value (Ea: 17.53 ± 2 kJ mol ) for the model reaction. © 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
